attributes.title: Do age differences in 1/f noise affect age-related slowing of resting EEG alpha?
attributes.description: Age related changes in neural oscillations, such as a slowing of frequency and a decrease in power, have been well established in previous research. However, neural “noise” has also been shown to change with age. This noise is considered an aperiodic component of the neural signal and has been shown to affect periodic components of the signal (i.e. oscillations), making it physiologically meaningful. Further, the 1/f component of the aperiodic signal has been found to represent the decoupling of population spiking activity from oscillatory synchronization. This desynchronization leads to a flatter 1/f slope which could help explain a decrease in cognitive function with age. In this study, we investigate how the role of the 1/f component of the aperiodic signal changes with age.

q1.value: Do age differences in 1/f noise affect age-related slowing of resting EEG alpha?

q2.value: Ashley Merkin, Lynton Graetz, Sabrina Sghirripa, Nigel Rogasch, Ashleigh Smith, Brenton Hordacre, Richard Harris, Julia Pitcher, John Semmler, Mitchell Goldsworthy

q3.value:
Aging is associated with many physical, biological, and cognitive changes which can greatly impact one’s physical and mental health. From mid to late life, the brain is particularly affected by age-related decline, both in brain morphology and physiological dynamics, each of which has been linked to changes in behavior and cognition (Harada et al., 2013; Phillips and Andres, 2010). For example, neural oscillatory dynamic changes with age include a shift from low-frequency oscillations that are dominant throughout childhood, towards higher frequency alpha oscillations that are more prominent in adulthood (Michels et al., 2013). Many studies have shown evidence for a decrease in neural oscillatory frequency and power in an old, relative to young, population, especially in the alpha range (Babiloni et al., 2006; Scally et al., 2018; Grandy et al., 2013; Vaden et al., 2012). Used as a tool to assess this “alpha slowing”, individual peak alpha frequency has been found to represent an individual, physiological characteristic that increases from childhood to adulthood, but begins slowing around mid-life (Michels et al., 2013; Scally et al., 2018).  

However, recent research has shed light on other components of the EEG broadband signal that could have implications for how past findings should be interpreted. Neural oscillations, also known as the “periodic” component of an EEG signal, are among the most common data types extracted from EEG recordings both at rest and during task performance and can be used to asses a change in cognitive state with regard to age. However, an “aperiodic” component, also known as background noise, exists within the EEG signal as well. This aperiodic component is characterised by a 1/f power-law distribution, and has been found to change with age, task demands, and behavioural state (Grigolini et al., 2009; Haller et al., 2018; Voytek et al., 2015a). Most research to date has used predefined frequency bands to look for neural oscillations within a dataset without regard to the aperiodic signal. This is problematic as aperiodic components have features that are independent of the periodic signal; in fact, neural oscillations are defined as regions of the power spectrum which rise above the background noise. This not only suggests neural oscillatory power should be measured separately from background noise, but further, oscillations should be measured relative to the aperiodic 1/f signal. Therefore, what is considered a neural oscillation using traditional EEG signal analysis methods may not represent a true oscillation, but rather a change in the aperiodic offset or slope within the dynamic 1/f signal (Haller et al., 2018; Ouyang et al., 2020). 

A recent study by Ouyang et al. (2020) looked at the effect of 1/f noise on alpha oscillatory activity in healthy young adults. Using a processing speed task, they found a significant and predictive association between alpha activity and cognitive ability. Structural equation modelling was then used to separate non-oscillatory 1/f activity from oscillatory alpha activity, as it has been shown previously that 1/f noise infiltrates the entire broadband spectrum and can confound oscillatory activity (Dave et al., 2018; Voytek at al., 2015a; Haller et al., 2018). After accounting for the 1/f component within the EEG signal, alpha oscillations were not found to be significantly correlated with specific cognitive processes as measured by a processing speed task. This provides evidence that the narrowband spectrum employed by most EEG research to date, and the results that were interpreted without regard to the 1/f background component, may not be accurately representing the physiological processes occurring in these neural systems. 
 
 A number of recent studies have sought to determine age-related changes in oscillatory activity while taking into account the 1/f component. Recent evidence suggests that as age increases, the 1/f spectral slope flattens, reflecting an increase in asynchronous neuronal population spiking (Voytek et al., 2015a; Voytek and Knight, 2015b). Local population spiking rates are influenced as a result of changes within the excitation/inhibition balance, and maintaining temporally synchronized and functional activity levels through this balance is an integral part of the healthy brain, affecting the ability to form oscillations, efficient information transfer, and working memory maintenance (Gao et al., 2017; Tatti et al., 2017). Abilities of the healthy brain have been shown to degenerate as age increases, and the 1/f signal is susceptible to the same age-related changes (Voytek et al., 2015a; Dave et al., 2018; Haller et al., 2018). Despite previous evidence found in task-based studies, it remains largely unknown if age differences in the 1/f component affect oscillatory components of resting EEG signal.

q4.value: In the present study, we investigate age differences in resting EEG signal with regard to the 1/f component. We hypothesize 1) peak alpha frequency and power will decrease in older, relative to younger, adults; 2) the 1/f slope will decrease in an old relative to young adults; 3) age differences in alpha peak frequency and power will be altered once the aperiodic background is removed from the periodic signal.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between subject design

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: The data set for the present study is a combination of six pre-existing data sets. The analyses planned for the present study (finding age differences in alpha peak frequency and power with regard to the 1/f background) are completely novel, and were not conducted in any of the previous studies. Therefore no existing patterns or summary statistics from previous studies are relevant to the present study.

question.value:
Participants
Healthy adult participants were recruited using a combination of study flyers located around campus and community groups, university staff newsletters and social media, and existing laboratory databases. Participants were financially compensated to cover travel costs and any other inconveniences incurred due to participation in the study and is consistent with previous brain stimulation studies run by our group.

Young adults were at least 18 years of age and all older adults were without cognitive impairment, as assessed using either Mini-Mental State Examination (score >24) (Folstein et al., 1975) or Addenbrooke’s Cognitive Examination (ACE-III) (score >82) (Mioshi et al., 2006). Exclusion criteria were history of psychological or neurological disease, a history of drug abuse, medications that alter the function of the nervous system, and an uncorrected hearing or visual impairment. All participants gave written consent and the studies were approved by the University of Adelaide Human Research Ethics Committee, The Queen Elizabeth Hospital Human Research Ethics Committee, and the University of South Australia Human Research Ethics Committee. 

EEG data acquisition
Participants were seated in a comfortable chair in a quiet room. They were asked to keep their eyes closed during recording, to remain as still, quiet and relaxed as possible, and to refrain from actively engaging in any cognitive or mental tasks. EEG data were recorded for 3 minutes from either 57 or 62 electrodes arranged in a 10-10 layout (Waveguard, ANT Neuro, Enschede, The Netherlands) using a Polybench TMSi EEG system (Twente Medical Systems International B.V, Oldenzaal, The Netherlands) or an ASA-lab EEG system (ANT Neuro, Enschede, Netherlands). Conductive gel was inserted into each electrode using a blunt-needle syringe in order to reduce impedance to <5 kΩ. The ground electrode was located at AFz. Signals were sampled at 2048 Hz, amplified 20x, online filtered (DC-553 Hz), and referenced to the average of all electrodes.

q13.value: Data were combined from six similarly designed studies that all included an eyes-closed resting EEG recording, resulting in 86 younger adults (mean age: 22.15 years, SD: 3.88, age range 17-35, 37 male) and 92 older adults (mean age: 65.08 years, SD: 8.18, age range 50-86, 54 male) in the final sample.

question.value:
Age (young vs old)
Aperiodic status (1/f background included vs 1/f background removed)

EEG pre-processing
Resting EEG data were pre-processed using EEGLAB (Delorme and Makeig, 2004) and customized scripts in MATLAB (R2019a, The Mathworks, USA). Bad and unused channels were removed. Data were then band-pass (1-100 Hz) and band-stop (48-52 Hz) filtered, down-sampled to 256 Hz, and epoched in 2-second segments. Independent Component Analysis (ICA) was run using the fastICA algorithm (Hyvarinen and Oja, 2000) to correct for artefacts caused by eye blinks or excessive muscle activity. An additional visual inspection was done to identify any additional artefacts or bad trials, and remove them from the data set. 

Spectral Analysis
Power spectral densities will be calculated for each electrode with 0.5 Hz resolution using Welch’s method. Peak alpha frequency (defined as the frequency with largest logarithmic power between 6 and 13 Hz) and the power at the peak will first be assessed without controlling for the 1/f component. We will then use the open-source Python toolbox FOOOF (‘fitting oscillations and one over f’) (Haller et al., 2018) to extract periodic (centre frequency, amplitude, and bandwidth of alpha oscillations) and aperiodic (1/f slope and offset) components for comparison between age groups.

Statistical Analyses 

We will use cluster-based statistics to examine age differences in peak alpha frequency and power (Aim 1), 1/f slope and offset (Aim 2), and the centre frequency, amplitude, and bandwidth of alpha oscillations after the aperiodic background is removed from the periodic signal (Aim 3). As an additional exploratory analysis, correlations between 1/f parameters and alpha peak frequency and power will be tested based on results from previous analyses.

Non-parametric cluster based statistics will be used to protect against multiple comparison errors that appear when comparing across multiple spatial and temporal domains. Clusters will be defined as 2 or more neighboring electrodes with a P value <0.05. A permutation distribution will be created using the Monte Carlo method (5000 permutations), and a cluster will be deemed significant if the cluster statistic (sum of all t-statistics within each cluster) is P < 0.025 compared to the permutation distribution (two-tailed).

q21.value: Cluster will be deemed significant if the cluster statistic (sum of all t-statistics within each cluster) is P < 0.025 compared to the permutation distribution (two-tailed).

q24.value: Correlations between 1/f parameters and alpha peak frequency and power will be tested based on results from previous analyses.

q25.value:

registration_responses.q8.question: Between subject design
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants
Healthy adult participants were recruited using a combination of study flyers located around campus and community groups, university staff newsletters and social media, and existing laboratory databases. Participants were financially compensated to cover travel costs and any other inconveniences incurred due to participation in the study and is consistent with previous brain stimulation studies run by our group.

attributes.title: Another’s Pain in my Social Brain: The Effects of Placebo (Empathy) Analgesia on Social Behavior
attributes.description: The shared representations account of empathy suggests that sharing other people’s emotions relies on neural processes similar to those engaged when experiencing such emotions oneself. Recent research corroborated this account by showing that experimentally reducing first-hand pain by means of placebo analgesia also resulted in reduced empathy for pain, and decreased activation in the shared neural networks. However, what has not been investigated yet, but is of much greater relevance, is whether the effects of placebo analgesia transfer to actual behavior. In other words, it is still not clear if the reduced empathic abilities, induced with placebo analgesia, have an influence on moral social behavior, that we show towards other, e.g. helping someone in need. With this project we therefore want to investigate in greater detail, to what extent placebo analgesia shows an effect on prosocial behavior.

summary.value:
This is an addendum to the preregistration of this project (https://osf.io/g3acp), uploaded on August 25th, 2019. There, we wrote: 

"In the first analysis, the dependent variable is represented by the self- and other-directed pain ratings. A second analysis will include the self-directed pain ratings as well as the other-directed unpleasantness ratings as the dependent variable. The independent variables will be treatment, target and intensity in both analyses. The focus in these two analyses will be on significant treatment*intensity interactions (= indication that placebo analgesia changes the difference between pain and no pain conditions) and non-significant 3-way interactions between treatment*intensity*target (= no difference in the placebo effect between first-hand and empathy for pain)."
 
This was a mistake on our part, since the use of the factor target (self vs. other) only applies to the first analysis where self- and other-related pain ratings are compared. Regarding unpleasantness, we did not collect other-, but only self-related unpleasantness ratings. Since pain and unpleasantness aim to measure two different aspects of the empathic response, it does not make sense to compare them within one analysis. The correct analysis is therefore an ANOVA using the unpleasantness ratings as the DV and the factors intensity and treatment (see also our previous preregistration where we preregistered the correct analysis: https://osf.io/uwzb5).

Furthermore, we would like to add additional information regarding the stopping rule. We wrote in the original preregistration that we will exclude non-responders to the placebo induction based on three criteria, the first being "any verbally expressed doubts about the analgesic effects of the pill or pain medication in general as well as about the study setup (e.g. confederate or other deceptive parts) after the experiment by means of feedback questions". Under "Data exclusion", we wrote "Additional exclusion criteria are expressed doubts about the setup of the study, and for the placebo group also low belief scores regarding the effectiveness of the placebo treatment and strong decreases between the first and second effectiveness measure, as well as more than three needed conditioning trials (see above for a thorough description of placebo non-responder identification)."

Since our original preregistration might seem unclear regarding this, we want to clarify that the exclusion criteria "doubts" applies both to participants in the placebo and the control group. In addition to the already preregistered non-responder criteria for the placebo group, we will exclude and replace any participant expressing serious doubts about any deceptive element of the study (e.g. not believing that the second person existed or received shocks). This will make sure that the final sample of 90 participants only consists of participants who believed the cover story.

The data collection of this project is currently ongoing and we have not started analyzing at the data yet. We recently noticed these mistakes/omissions and wanted to disclose them as soon as possible by adding them to the preregistered plan before beginning with data inspection and analysis.

registration_responses.summary:
This is an addendum to the preregistration of this project (https://osf.io/g3acp), uploaded on August 25th, 2019. There, we wrote: 

"In the first analysis, the dependent variable is represented by the self- and other-directed pain ratings. A second analysis will include the self-directed pain ratings as well as the other-directed unpleasantness ratings as the dependent variable. The independent variables will be treatment, target and intensity in both analyses. The focus in these two analyses will be on significant treatment*intensity interactions (= indication that placebo analgesia changes the difference between pain and no pain conditions) and non-significant 3-way interactions between treatment*intensity*target (= no difference in the placebo effect between first-hand and empathy for pain)."
 
This was a mistake on our part, since the use of the factor target (self vs. other) only applies to the first analysis where self- and other-related pain ratings are compared. Regarding unpleasantness, we did not collect other-, but only self-related unpleasantness ratings. Since pain and unpleasantness aim to measure two different aspects of the empathic response, it does not make sense to compare them within one analysis. The correct analysis is therefore an ANOVA using the unpleasantness ratings as the DV and the factors intensity and treatment (see also our previous preregistration where we preregistered the correct analysis: https://osf.io/uwzb5).

Furthermore, we would like to add additional information regarding the stopping rule. We wrote in the original preregistration that we will exclude non-responders to the placebo induction based on three criteria, the first being "any verbally expressed doubts about the analgesic effects of the pill or pain medication in general as well as about the study setup (e.g. confederate or other deceptive parts) after the experiment by means of feedback questions". Under "Data exclusion", we wrote "Additional exclusion criteria are expressed doubts about the setup of the study, and for the placebo group also low belief scores regarding the effectiveness of the placebo treatment and strong decreases between the first and second effectiveness measure, as well as more than three needed conditioning trials (see above for a thorough description of placebo non-responder identification)."

Since our original preregistration might seem unclear regarding this, we want to clarify that the exclusion criteria "doubts" applies both to participants in the placebo and the control group. In addition to the already preregistered non-responder criteria for the placebo group, we will exclude and replace any participant expressing serious doubts about any deceptive element of the study (e.g. not believing that the second person existed or received shocks). This will make sure that the final sample of 90 participants only consists of participants who believed the cover story.

The data collection of this project is currently ongoing and we have not started analyzing at the data yet. We recently noticed these mistakes/omissions and wanted to disclose them as soon as possible by adding them to the preregistered plan before beginning with data inspection and analysis.

q1.value: When does the future self start?

q3.value: Chronological age may be an objectively-determined fact, but people differ in their perceptions of how old they feel, as well as how close they are to becoming older, more mature versions of themselves (i.e., their future self). How do such perceptions vary across the span of a high school education, and are there individual differences that may be intensified by proximity to graduation? Finally, what might be the relationship between subjective perceptions of age and important education outcomes such as GPA, attendance, and motivation?

q4.value: If students believe that their future selves begin in time earlier, they will have higher GPAs.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a correlational design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants for this study will be students recruited through the Character Lab Research Network (CLRN), an online data collection platform working with a network of partner schools to administer online questionnaires and behavioral tasks.
 
CLRN studies are conducted on previously set and agreed upon dates over the course of a few weeks with all partner schools. These dates occur three times in a school year (fall, winter, and spring). We will also collect information from school records such as GPA, attendance, and free/reduced lunch status.
 
CLRN will work with schools to collect data from school records and link it to study data, then deliver the merged, de-identified dataset to the researchers.
 
For more information on the Character Lab Research Network, please refer to https://characterlab.org/research-network.

q13.value: Units of analysis are students. Number of students is determined by how many are in the classrooms that are assigned to us.

q15.value: This study will be run through CLRN’s Qualtrics-supported online platform that randomizes all students at the network schools into multiple CLRN studies on their predetermined testing day. This study has a quota equal to the sample size specified above.

question.value: Perceptions of when the future self will start (quantitative question) and GPA.

We will regress GPA on perceptions of when future self starts. In an exploratory way, we also plan on analyzing the distributions of these variables, and looking at how future self perceptions differ across grade and age.

Finally, what might be the relationship between subjective perceptions of age and important education outcomes such as GPA, attendance, and motivation?
